Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a multi-electrode array (MEA) with active recruiting of cells and mechanically confined neuronal networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop a sophisticated platform for investigating small networks of dissociated neurons, based on monitoring their electrical activity. The targeted platform is a multielectrode array (MEA) tool, distinguished by very accurate patterning of neuronal networks using mechanical and chemical methods. By virtue of its superior signal-to-noise ratio, this tool will have transformative impact in all fields of cell-based sensors and neuroscience by enabling repeatable and sensitive experiments.
This tool can be used for investigating the highly complex processes of learning and memory in a systematic and simplified manner within cultured cells. It can be also used in the pharmacological industry as a test bed for examining the influence of pharmacological agents on neurons. Alternatively, it can be used as a cell-based sensor, in which changes in electrical activity may be indicative of the presence of neuroactive compounds. In this project, it will also be used as a training tool in bioengineering labs and as a demonstration unit for a summer program targeting middle school girls to increase the number of female engineering students at Lehigh University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the lifetime of this project, we have accomplished our major goal and developed a novel platform for neuroscience applications.  That was achieved through achieving our stepping-stones, notably developing technology to form patterned neuronal networks using either chemical or mechanical cues for cell growth, as well as developing the technique to separate glial and hippocampal neurons. We have also accomplished an achievement that was not expected at the beginning of this project: we have developed a method to estimate the physical properties of neurons and glial cells using dielectrophoresis crossover frequency.

 

First, we have developed a multielectrode array where precise positioning of primary mouse hippocampal neurons was accomplished via positive dielectrophoresis (DEP) applied to actively recruit hippocampal neurons to the electrodes of MEA, whereas microstructures such as chambers and trenches are created to effectively define a patterned neuronal network. We have also investigated the effective pretreatment methods to improve cytocompatibility of certain structural materials for MEAs, such as cured thin SU-8 epoxy. The functionality of our novel MEA is proven by the successful recording of spontaneous and stimulated neuronal potentials from primary hippocampal neurons, including the propagation of evoked neuronal bursts between electrodes. This work was the subject of our journal papers published in Biomedical Microdevices.

 

In order to perform successful recruiting and trapping using positive dielectrophoresis, we have performed the modeling and experimental verification of parameters (voltage, frequency and cell suspension medium). This work was the subject of our conference paper published on international conference.

 

The important step in developing this device was setting up the parameters for dielectrophoretic recruiting and trapping in such a manner as to trap only hippocampal neurons and not glial cells. We have determined via modeling (and then experimentally verified it) a DEP frequency suitable for trapping exclusively hippocampal neurons via positive dielectrophoresis while repelling glial cells (present in the same cell culturing medium) from the very same electrodes via negative dielectrophoresis. This technique if a valuable addition to the toolbox for creating more functional and versatile multi-electrode arrays. This work was the subject of our second journal paper, published in Biomedical Microdevices.

 

Finally, we have used this work in the way not originally anticipated and we have successfully determined the ranges of dielectric permittivity, cytoplasm conductivity and specific membrane capacitance of mouse hippocampal neuronal and glial cells using dielectrophoresis crossover frequency. This methodology is applicable to any type of cultured cell that can be subjected to both positive and negative dielectrophoresis.  It helped determine some ranges of above-mentioned properties for glial cells, which were not sufficiently well known and were very rarely addressed in literature. This work was the subject of our third journal paper, published in Journal of Biological Physics.


Last Modified: 07/30/2017
Modified by: Svetlana Tatic-Lucic

That was achieved through achieving our stepping-stones, notably developing technology to form patterned neuronal networks using either chemical or mechanical cues for cell growth, as well as developing the technique to separate glial and hippocampal neurons. First, we have developed a multielectrode array where precise positioning of primary mouse hippocampal neurons was accomplished via positive dielectrophoresis (DEP) applied to actively recruit hippocampal neurons to the electrodes of MEA, whereas microstructures such as chambers and trenches are created to effectively define a patterned neuronal network. We have also investigated the effective pretreatment methods to improve cytocompatibility of certain structural materials for MEAs, such as cured thin SU-8 epoxy. The functionality of our novel MEA is proven by the successful recording of spontaneous and stimulated neuronal potentials from primary hippocampal neurons, including the propagation of evoked neuronal bursts between electrodes. This work was the subject of our journal papers published in Biomedical Microdevices. In order to perform successful recruiting and trapping using positive dielectrophoresis, we have performed the modeling and experimental verification of parameters (voltage, frequency and cell suspension medium). This work was the subject of our conference paper published on international conference.
